rev.diff:
Line 132: Line 132:
{{cquote|OS/2 offered excellent compatibility with DOS and Windows 3.1 applications. No, this is not an error. Many application vendors argued that by developing a DOS or Windows app, they would reach the OS/2 market in addition to DOS/Windows markets and they didn't develop native OS/2 applications.}}
{{cquote|OS/2 offered excellent compatibility with DOS and Windows 3.1 applications. No, this is not an error. Many application vendors argued that by developing a DOS or Windows app, they would reach the OS/2 market in addition to DOS/Windows markets and they didn't develop native OS/2 applications.}}
  +   +
A counter-argument to this would be the fact that users can already use several [[Virtual Machine]]s to run almost all windows programs, so using that line of reasoning, VMs could make developers even less likely to develop native applications, but it is clear that arguing against a Virtual Machine is arguing against flexibility.
